#Text=International conference agrees on plan for Yemen 's terror problem
#Text=Thursday , January 28 , 2010
#Text=An international conference in London on Tuesday came up with a plan to fight al-Qaeda 's presence in Yemen .
#Text=Delegates present at the conference were from twenty countries , including Yemen , the United Kingdom , and the United States .
#Text=David Miliband , chair of the conference .
#Text=Image : Munich Security Conference .
#Text=The conference was called by British Prime Minister Gordon Brown due to the failed Christmas Day plot to blow up a US plane , for which al-Qaeda in Yemen claimed responsibility .
#Text=However , the attendees stress that the al-Qaeda presence is not Yemen 's only problem , and that it cannot be solved without first dealing with the others .
#Text=we — the international community — can and must do more .
#Text=— Hillary Clinton
#Text=Hillary Clinton , the US Secretary of State , said that bringing peace to Yemen and making it more stable is a major priority for the United States .
#Text=She said that the United States had signed a three-year agreement on security development in Yemen .
#Text=" To help the people of Yemen , we — the international community — can and must do more .

column1: #Text=Also present were delegates from the United Nations , European Union , and World Bank .

#Text=Miliband acknowledged that the solution was not simply a military one by saying at a press conference , " It 's been a common feature of every contribution that we have heard today that the assault on Yemen 's problems cannot begin and end with its security challenges and its counter-terrorism strategy .

column3:
_	_	_	_
26-15	2871-2872	.	_	_	_	_

#Text=Ali Mujawar , the Prime Minister of Yemen , received this support warmly , but said that any attack on the nation 's sovereignty would be considered  unacceptable " , and that it should not be portrayed as a failing nation , despite a multitude of problems , including its damaged economy , rapidly growing population , and shrinking oil reserves , as well as the beginning of a drought and its problems with insurgents , such as al-Qaeda terrorists .

column1: #Text=British Foreign Office Minister Ivan Lewis echoed Mujawar 's statements by saying that Yemen is " not a failed state " , but " an incredibly fragile state " .
#Text=Lewis also said that " [ s]upporting the government of Yemen is crucial to the stability of that country but it is also crucial to the stability of the world " .

#Text=Yemen 's Foreign Minister , Abu Bakr al-Qirbi , asked the delegates at the conference for " international support to build infrastructure , combat poverty and create jobs , as well as support in combating terrorism " .
#Text=However , he said that the idea of having US military bases in Yemen was " inconceivable " .
#Text=Arab League secretary general Amr Moussa is unsure how useful the meeting will be .

#Text=He expressed these concerns by telling the BBC , " I do n't know how a conference like that can decide something useful , something reasonable for Yemen ... in a couple of hours " , and saying that it was a " strange " and " very unusual sign " that the Arab League had not been given the chance to send delegates to the conference , despite wanting to discuss all of Yemen 's problems without specific focus on al-Qaeda .
#Text=Despite these concerns , donors from a number of Western and Gulf nations have agreed to meed again , this time in the Saudi Arabian capital city of Riyadh , in February .
